custom_margin_last_edited="on|tablet" custom_padding="||0px||false|false" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}" header_2_line_height__hover_enabled="off|desktop"]

Schedule an Annual Full-Body Skin Exam

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Divider-small-new-yellow.png" title_text="Divider" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" custom_margin="||||false|false" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="default" text_font="Roboto||||||||" text_font_size="20px" text_line_height="33px" text_orientation_tablet="left" text_orientation_phone="center" text_orientation_last_edited="on|phone" global_colors_info="{}"]

Patients with numerous moles on their skin, outdoor jobs or hobbies that expose them to frequent, prolonged sunlight, or those with a personal or family history of skin cancer should have their skin examined annually.Â 

This appointment will typically take around 15 minutes and no more than a half-hour - depending on whether any skin biopsies are necessary. After having you change into a medical gown, the doctor will examine your entire body, including hard-to-see areas such as your scalp, behind your ears, your back, between your toes, and, when warranted, the buttocks and genitals. We will closely examine any particular areas of concern or areas. If there are any areas that you would prefer we not examine, we respect that.

Due to our training, experience, and focus on skin cancer detection, we often diagnose a variety of skin conditions that often otherwise go unnoticed and untreated. We will ask you about your medical history and family history and may have you point out any areas of concern.Â 

Â Dermatologists are trained and experienced and understand the most subtle signs of cancer and other skin conditions. Our providers use a polarized magnifying glass called a dermatoscope to examine any suspicious spots on your skin. Sometimes alcohol or oil is used better to see the texture of spots on your skin, and the doctor may even take a digital photo of the area for further examination.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section][et_pb_section fb_built="1" custom_padding_last_edited="on|tablet" admin_label="About Section" _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="default" background_color="RGBA(255,255,255,0)" background_enable_image="off" custom_margin_tablet="0px||0px||false|false" custom_margin_phone="0px||0px||false|false" custom_margin_last_edited="on|tablet" custom_padding="100px||100px||false|false" custom_padding_tablet="50px||30px||false|false" custom_padding_phone="50px||50px||false|false" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}"][et_pb_row column_structure="1_2,1_2" make_equal="on" module_class="row-reverse" _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="default" custom_margin="0px||0px||true|false" custom_padding="0px||0px||true|false" global_colors_info="{}"][et_pb_column type="1_2" _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="default" background_image="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/Kelsie-Bogdan-Adrienne-Keely1.jpg" border_radii="on|8px|8px|8px|8px" global_colors_info="{}"][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type="1_2" _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="default" custom_padding_tablet="35px||0px||false|false" custom_padding_phone="50px||0px||false|false" custom_padding_last_edited="on|tablet" global_colors_info="{}"][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="5f610831-85d0-4eae-810b-b1fd2a189de5" global_colors_info="{}"]

Skin Biopsies

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Divider-small-new-yellow.png" title_text="Divider" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="399dc1c6-5b92-4bd9-a1dd-0455d30e3551" global_colors_info="{}"]

If your doctor notices any suspicious growths or moles, they may order a biopsy of the spot. A skin biopsy procedure involves removing a small piece of skin for examination under a microscope by a pathologist.Â 

A skin biopsy is necessary to diagnose skin cancers and is required by insurance companies before your dermatologist can perform any skin cancer treatments.

There are three types of skin biopsies:

[/et_pb_text][dsm_icon_list _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}"][dsm_icon_list_child text="A punch biopsy uses a specialized circular tool to remove a small plug of skin." use_icon="off" image="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/checklist_icon.png" image_padding="10px" image_max_width="30px" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" text_font="Roboto||||||||" text_font_size="20px" text_line_height="26px" custom_margin_last_edited="off|desktop" custom_padding="||10px||false|false" custom_padding_last_edited="off|desktop" border_color_all_icon="#000000" global_colors_info="{}"][/dsm_icon_list_child][dsm_icon_list_child text="A shave biopsy involves using a razor to thinly remove a sample." use_icon="off" image="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/checklist_icon.png" image_padding="10px" image_max_width="30px" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" text_font="Roboto||||||||" text_font_size="20px" text_line_height="26px" custom_margin_last_edited="off|desktop" custom_padding="||10px||false|false" custom_padding_last_edited="off|desktop" border_color_all_icon="#000000" global_colors_info="{}"][/dsm_icon_list_child][dsm_icon_list_child text="An excisional biopsy requires a scalpel to remove the entire spot to examine the whole spot under the microscope." use_icon="off" image="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/checklist_icon.png" image_padding="10px" image_max_width="30px" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" text_font="Roboto||||||||" text_font_size="20px" text_line_height="26px" custom_margin_last_edited="off|desktop" custom_padding="||10px||false|false" custom_padding_last_edited="off|desktop" border_color_all_icon="#000000" global_colors_info="{}"][/dsm_icon_list_child][/dsm_icon_list][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section][et_pb_section fb_built="1" custom_padding_last_edited="on|tablet" admin_label="About Section" _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="default" background_enable_color="off" background_enable_image="off" custom_margin_tablet="0px||0px||false|false" custom_margin_phone="0px||0px||false|false" custom_margin_last_edited="on|tablet" custom_padding="100px||100px||false|false" custom_padding_tablet="50px||30px||false|false" custom_padding_phone="50px||50px||false|false" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}"][et_pb_row column_structure="1_2,1_2" make_equal="on" module_class="row-reverse" _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="default" custom_margin="0px||0px||true|false" custom_padding="0px||0px||true|false" global_colors_info="{}"][et_pb_column type="1_2" _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="default" custom_padding_tablet="35px||0px||false|false" custom_padding_phone="50px||0px||false|false" custom_padding_last_edited="on|tablet" custom_css_main_element="margin: auto;" global_colors_info="{}"][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="399dc1c6-5b92-4bd9-a1dd-0455d30e3551" global_colors_info="{}"]

The type of biopsy you require will is determined by your doctor and depends on the size, shape, and location of the lesion being examined.Â 

This is a quick and minimally invasive procedure, so youâll be able to return to your day afterward. Your medical team may administer localized anesthesia and give you stitches if necessary. You should care for the area by keeping it clean and moisturized and following any after-care instructions given to you by your doctor.Â 

Your doctor will call you to discuss your results in 2-7 days.Â

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Search engines treat links to your website as a 'third party vote' in favour of your website - like a vote of confidence. meta._wds_title: Skin Exams | Full Body | Spot Check | Female Dermatologist
meta._wds_metadesc: We examine spots on the skin, as well as perform full-body skin examinations. We will biopsy suspicious skin lesions to rule out skin cancer.
meta._wds_trimmed_excerpt: Skin Exams and Biopsies Detecting Skin Cancers With Skin Exams and Biopsies Skin cancer comes in a few forms, and the signs are telltale to a trained eye, so it is imperative to make an appointment with your dermatologist to conduct a full-body skin exam when indicated or you have areas of conce ...
meta._wds_focus-keywords: Skin Cancer examinations biopsy Dermatologist near me full body skin exam

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Divider-small-new-yellow.png" title_text="Divider" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" global_colors_info="{}"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="399dc1c6-5b92-4bd9-a1dd-0455d30e3551" text_font_size="22px" custom_margin_tablet="||20px||false|false" custom_margin_phone="||30px||false|false" custom_margin_last_edited="on|phone" global_colors_info="{}"]

After the skin cancer removal, the area left behind will need to be fixed. There are many important considerations when creating a plan to fix the defect. It is crucial to choose a surgeon that is both well-trained for this specific task and has a lot of experience performing it. Dr. Mario is one of the best-trained and highest-volume Mohs surgeons in the United States. He cares deeply about creating a positive environment for patients and staff, communicating with patients before, during, and after surgery, and continually measuring and improving the outcomes of his work.

[/et_pb_text][dsm_icon_list _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}"][dsm_icon_list_child text="Fixing defects in the skin after skin cancer removal is different from aesthetic/cosmetic plastic surgery such as facelifts, breast augmentation, liposuction, and tummy tucks. It requires additional knowledge, skills, training, and experience, particularly expert knowledge in tissue dynamics, local skin flaps, grafting, and advanced wound healing techniques." use_icon="off" image="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/checklist_icon.png" image_padding="10px" image_max_width="30px" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" text_font="Roboto|500|||||||" text_font_size="20px" text_line_height="26px" custom_margin_last_edited="off|desktop" custom_padding="||10px||false|false" custom_padding_last_edited="off|desktop" border_color_all_icon="#000000" global_colors_info="{}"][/dsm_icon_list_child][dsm_icon_list_child text="Fellowship-trained Mohs surgeons typically have the most appropriate training and experience to fix 99 percent of defects after skin cancer excision." use_icon="off" image="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/checklist_icon.png" image_padding="10px" image_max_width="30px" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" text_font="Roboto|500|||||||" text_font_size="20px" text_line_height="26px" custom_margin_last_edited="off|desktop" custom_padding="||10px||false|false" custom_padding_last_edited="off|desktop" border_color_all_icon="#000000" global_colors_info="{}"][/dsm_icon_list_child][dsm_icon_list_child text="The Mohs surgery and the reconstruction are completed the same day in our outpatient clinic using only local anesthesia. Going under general anesthesia is typically unnecessary." use_icon="off" image="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/checklist_icon.png" image_padding="10px" image_max_width="30px" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" text_font="Roboto|500|||||||" text_font_size="20px" text_line_height="26px" custom_margin_last_edited="off|desktop" custom_padding="||10px||false|false" custom_padding_last_edited="off|desktop" border_color_all_icon="#000000" global_colors_info="{}"][/dsm_icon_list_child][dsm_icon_list_child text="A small percentage of defects may be better closed in the operating room under general anesthesia. Dr. Mario will discuss this option with you when appropriate. " use_icon="off" image="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/checklist_icon.png" image_padding="10px" image_max_width="30px" _builder_version="4.17.4" About Mohs Skin Cancer Surgery

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Divider.svg" title_text="Divider" _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="399dc1c6-5b92-4bd9-a1dd-0455d30e3551" global_colors_info="{}"]

Here at Southern Skies, our dermatologists specialize in Mohs skin cancer surgery - it is the focus of our office. Our surgeons have decades of experience and are well-known for their success after treating hundreds of patients who have been diagnosed with skin cancer. We believe in educating our patients thoroughly about this procedure so they are confident when it happens. Mohs has a 99 percent cure rate, studies show.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_button button_text="Request Appointment" _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="9db9c67f-904b-4a50-875e-2c4346f4d38d" custom_padding_tablet="" custom_padding_phone="" Frequently Asked Questions

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Divider-small-new-yellow.png" title_text="Divider" align="center" align_tablet="center" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_accordion open_toggle_text_color="#0B61C7" closed_toggle_background_color="#0B61C7" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="bfc4e6c6-6cf5-4fa5-80c5-c288eb96a643" border_color_all="#0B61C7" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}"][et_pb_accordion_item title="What's the difference between cosmetic/aesthetic surgery and reconstructive plastic surgery?" open="on" _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="default" body_line_height="33px" global_colors_info="{}"]

Cosmetic plastic surgery is purely for aesthetic reasons; examples include breast augmentation, rhinoplasty, blepharoplasty, neck lifts, and tummy tucks. It generally exists to improve the look and shape of existing structures. The type of reconstructive plastic surgery that we focus on is used to fix a defect left in the skin after skin cancer has been surgically removed. The goal is that in 6-9 months, no one will know you ever had skin cancer.

Unlike aesthetic/cosmetic surgery, reconstructive surgery after skin cancer removal is almost always covered by medical insurance.

[/et_pb_accordion_item][et_pb_accordion_item title="What is the recovery time like for reconstructive plastic surgery?" _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="default" body_line_height="33px" global_colors_info="{}" open="off"]

There are different phases of recovery. Depending on the size and type of reconstructive repair, the immediate healing usually takes 1-2 weeks, when we will remove the sutures or dissolve them on their own. I typically tell patients that it looks better every day the first week after surgery, a little better every week the first month, then it continues to improve every month for the next 6-9 months. By 9-12 months, hopefully, no one will be able to tell you ever had skin cancer. You would be surprised at how large skin cancers we can treat with minimal scarring in one year.

[/et_pb_accordion_item][et_pb_accordion_item title=" Is reconstructive plastic surgery on the face safe?" _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="default" body_line_height="33px" global_colors_info="{}" open="off"]

Yes, most reconstructive plastic surgery we perform is on the head and neck, including the scalp, face, nose, eyelids, ears, and lips. When performed by a well-trained, experienced surgeon, the results are typically excellent. Of course, you will experience some pain, swelling, and possibly bruising, the severity of which depends on age, overall health, activity level, size of the skin cancer, and area worked on.

So far all your focus keywords are unique, way to go!";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. Doing so achieves a nice balance between populating your description with keywords to rank highly in search engines, and also keeping it to a readable length that won't be cut off in search engine results. Unfortunately there isn't a rule book for SEO meta descriptions, just remember to make your description great for SEO, but also (most importantly) readable and enticing for potential visitors to click on.";s:10:"status_msg";s:38:"Your meta description is a good length";}s:13:"slug_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:181:"You've got your focus keywords in the page slug which can help your page rank as you have a higher chance of matching search terms, and Google does index your page URL, great stuff!";s:9:"more_info";s:403:"The page URL you use for this post will be visible in search engine results, so it's important to also include words that the searcher is looking for (your focus keywords). It's debatable whether keywords in the slug are of any real search engine ranking benefit. One could assume that because the slug does get indexed, the algorithm may favour slugs more closely aligned with the topic being searched.";s:10:"status_msg";s:46:"You've used your focus keyword in the page URL";}s:13:"keywords_used";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:148:"Focus keywords are intended to be unique so you're less likely to write duplicate content. Consider changing the focus keywords to something unique.";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. You can read more about this here. ";s:10:"status_msg";s:42:"You haven't used this focus keyword before";}s:16:"imgalts_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:305:"8/8 images on this page have alt text with your keyword(s) which is too much. Whilst itâs great that you have image alternative text with your focus keyword(s), you can also get penalized for having too many keywords on a page. Try to include your keyword(s) in image alt texts only when it makes sense.";s:9:"more_info";s:244:"Image alternative text attributes help search engines correctly index images, aid visually impaired readers, and the text is used in place of the image if it's unable to load. You should add alternative text for all images in your content.";s:10:"status_msg";s:61:"Too many of your image alt texts contain the focus keyword(s)";}s:14:"content_length";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:74:"Your content is longer than the recommend minimum of 300 words, excellent!";s:9:"more_info";s:798:"Content is ultimately the bread and butter of your SEO. Without words, your pages and posts will have a hard time ranking for the keywords you want them to. As a base for any article best practice suggests a minimum of 300 words, with 1000 being a good benchmark and 1600 being the optimal. Numerous studies have uncovered that longer content tends to perform better than shorter content, with pages having 1000 words or more performing best. Whilst optimizing your content for search engines is what we're going for here, a proven bi-product is that high quality long form articles also tend to get shared more on social platforms. With the increasing power of social media as a tool for traffic it's a nice flow on effect of writing those juicy high quality articles your readers are waiting for.";s:10:"status_msg";s:84:"The text contains 1039 words which is more than the recommended minimum of 300 words";}s:15:"keyword_density";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:196:"Currently you haven't used any keywords in your content. The recommended density is 1-3%. A low keyword density means your content has less chance of ranking highly for your chosen focus keywords.";s:9:"more_info";s:728:"Keyword density is all about making sure your content is populated with enough keywords to give it a better chance of appearing higher in search results. One way of making sure people will be able to find our content is using particular focus keywords, and using them as much as naturally possible in our content. In doing this we are trying to match up the keywords that people are likely to use when searching for this article or page, so try to get into your visitors mind and picture them typing a search into Google. While we recommend aiming for 1-3% density, remember content is king and you don't want your article to end up sounding like a robot. Get creative and utilize the page title, image caption, and subheadings.";s:10:"status_msg";s:33:"You haven't used any keywords yet";}s:11:"links_count";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:162:"Internal links help search engines crawl your website, effectively pointing them to more pages to index on your website. You've already added 36 links, nice work!";s:9:"more_info";s:1261:" Internal links are important for linking together related content. Search engines will 'crawl' through your website, indexing pages and posts as they go. To help them discover all the juicy content your website has to offer, it's wise to make sure your content has internal links built in for bots to follow and index.

External links don't benefit your SEO by having them in your own content, but you'll want to try and get as many other websites linking to your articles and pages as possible. Search engines treat links to your website as a 'third party vote' in favour of your website - like a vote of confidence. Since they're the hardest form of 'validation' to get (another website has to endorse you!) search engines weight them heavily when considering page rank. For more info: https://moz.com/learn/seo/internal-link

Note: This check is only looking at the content your page is outputting and doesn't include your main navigation. Blogs with lots of posts will benefit the most from this method, as it aids Google in finding and indexing all of your content, not just the latest articles. ";s:10:"status_msg";s:58:"You have 20 internal and 16 external links in your content";}s:13:"para_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:171:"You've included your focus keywords in the first paragraph of your content, which will help search engines and visitors quickly scope the topic of your article. Well done!";s:9:"more_info";s:541:"You should clearly formulate what your post is about in the first paragraph. In printed texts, a writer usually starts off with some kind of teaser, but there is no time for that if you are writing for the web. You only have seconds to gain your readerâs attention. Make sure the first paragraph tells the main message of your post. That way, you make it easy for your reader to figure out what your post is about. Doing this also tells Google what your post is about. Donât forget to put your focus keyword in that first paragraph! ";s:10:"status_msg";s:64:"The focus keyword appears in the first paragraph of your article";}s:20:"subheadings_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:152:"You've used keywords in 3 of your subheadings which will help both the user and search engines quickly figure out what your article is about, good work!";s:9:"more_info";s:478:"When trying to rank for certain keywords, those keywords should be found in as many key places as possible. Given that you're writing about the topic it only makes sense that you mention it in at least one of your subheadings. Headings are important for users as they break up your content and help readers figure out what the text is about. Same goes for search engines. With that said, don't force keywords into all your titles - keep it natural, readable, and use moderation!";s:10:"status_msg";s:45:"Your focus keyword was found in 3 subheadings";}}}

Adrienne Keely, CRNP

Certified Registered Nurse Practitioner

Adrienne Keely, CRNP has been working in Dermatology since 2016, where she has performed full-body skin cancer screenings and assisted in Mohs procedures and post-Mohs plastic surgery reconstruction.

Adrienne was born and raised in Vestavia Hills, Alabama, and graduated from Briarwood Christian High School. She went to Mississippi College, where she obtained a BS in Kinesiology in 2011...keep reading

Chelsi Davis, PA-C

Certified Physician Assistant

Chelsi Davis, PA-C, was born and raised in Chelsea, Alabama. She graduated with honors from Auburn University with a Bachelor of Science in Microbiology and a minor in Spanish in 2015. Consider changing the focus keywords to something unique.";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. Whilst optimizing your content for search engines is what we're going for here, a proven bi-product is that high quality long form articles also tend to get shared more on social platforms. You've already added 208 links, nice work!";s:9:"more_info";s:1261:" Internal links are important for linking together related content. Search engines will 'crawl' through your website, indexing pages and posts as they go. To help them discover all the juicy content your website has to offer, it's wise to make sure your content has internal links built in for bots to follow and index.

External links don't benefit your SEO by having them in your own content, but you'll want to try and get as many other websites linking to your articles and pages as possible. Search engines treat links to your website as a 'third party vote' in favour of your website - like a vote of confidence. Since they're the hardest form of 'validation' to get (another website has to endorse you!) search engines weight them heavily when considering page rank. For more info: https://moz.com/learn/seo/internal-link

Consider changing the focus keywords to something unique.";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. You've already added 7 links, nice work!";s:9:"more_info";s:1261:" Internal links are important for linking together related content. Search engines will 'crawl' through your website, indexing pages and posts as they go. To help them discover all the juicy content your website has to offer, it's wise to make sure your content has internal links built in for bots to follow and index.

External links don't benefit your SEO by having them in your own content, but you'll want to try and get as many other websites linking to your articles and pages as possible. Search engines treat links to your website as a 'third party vote' in favour of your website - like a vote of confidence. Since they're the hardest form of 'validation' to get (another website has to endorse you!) search engines weight them heavily when considering page rank. For more info: https://moz.com/learn/seo/internal-link

Note: This check is only looking at the content your page is outputting and doesn't include your main navigation. Blogs with lots of posts will benefit the most from this method, as it aids Google in finding and indexing all of your content, not just the latest articles. Make sure the first paragraph tells the main message of your post. That way, you make it easy for your reader to figure out what your post is about. âI was extremely pleased with my experience at Southern Skies. Dr. Mario and his NP, Adrienne, removed a large basal cell on the top of my lip. It was a very extensive procedure resulting in more than 40 external stitches. Within a month the scar was barely noticeable. Much care and thought were given to how and where to make the incisions. Taking into account my facial creases, wrinkles, etc., the scar is almost completely hidden. I recommend them highly!â

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Rebecca Long, Gadsden" button_url_new_window="1" use_rating="on" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" global_colors_info="{}"]

âIâm very pleased with the care and concern of this staff. Dr. M did a great job on my ear. The reconstruction looks wonderful. You have to look really close to tell anything was done. They are professionals, but they treat me like family.âÂ 

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Michael Brown, Ohatchee" button_url_new_window="1" use_rating="on" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" global_colors_info="{}"]

With more than 40 years in business, Southern Skies Dermatology and Surgery is proud to serve the Alabama communities of Trussville in Birmingham, Pell City, and Gadsden. As the third generation of physicians in this practice, we focus primarily on skin cancer diagnosis and treatment, which has resulted in our practice becoming one of the highest-volume skin cancer exam, biopsy, and treatment groups in the United States.

Our mentality is that by focusing our energy and attention on one thing, skin cancer, we can do that one thing phenomenally well.Â  If youâre looking for expert dermatologists in Birmingham, Pell City, or Gadsden, schedule your appointment with us today and see why so many of our patients trust us with their skin health!

What Makes Us Different

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Divider.svg" title_text="Divider" _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" custom_margin="||||false|false" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="default" text_font="Roboto||||||||" text_line_height="33px" text_orientation_tablet="left" text_orientation_phone="center" text_orientation_last_edited="on|phone" global_colors_info="{}"]

At Southern Skies Dermatology, we feel that the best way to create a first-class experience for our patients is to first create a first-class experience for our employees. By prioritizing our work culture and making Southern Skies Dermatology and Surgery a positive, fun, rewarding place to work - we believe that we attract exceptional employees.Â 

Our practice administrator, Michelle Flowers, once told Dr. Mario, that we have to make sure we donât âoverwork and underpayâ our staff or they wonât take pride in working here, and they wonât stick around for the long haul. Dr. Mario took that to heart and wanted to go even further.

We reward our team with free take-out for lunch every Thursday (group vote decision), a spin-the-wheel birthday prize, quarterly cash rewards for being a reliably consistent employee, regular raises, unexpected bonuses for exceptional performance, and a healthy Christmas bonus, as well as a fabulously fun Christmas party.Â Â 

Phenomenal patient care comes from a team that is invested and ready to contribute to our practice. Weâve built a work family that includes doctors, advanced practice providers, front office staff, medical assistants, billing staff, laboratory personnel, many wonderful local vendors, and most importantly our patients whom we are extremely proud of.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section]

Whilst it's recommended to try and get these words in, don't sacrifice readability and the quality of the SEO title just to rank higher - people may not want to click on it if it doesn't read well.";s:10:"status_msg";s:44:"The SEO title contains your focus keyword(s)";}s:12:"title_length";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:99:"Your SEO title is 52 characters which is between the recommended best practice of 50-65 characters.";s:9:"more_info";s:712:"Your SEO title is the most important element because it is what users will see in search engine results. You'll want to make sure that you have your focus keywords in there, that it's a nice length, and that people will want to click on it. Best practices suggest keeping your titles between 50 and 65 characters including spaces, though in some cases 60 is the sweetspot. The length is important both for SEO ranking but also how your title will show up in search engines - long titles will be cut off visually and look bad. Unfortunately there isn't a rule book for SEO titles, just remember to make your title great for SEO but also (most importantly) readable and enticing for potential visitors to click on.";s:10:"status_msg";s:31:"Your SEO title is a good length";}s:17:"metadesc_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:159:"The focus keyword for this article appears in the SEO description which means it has a better chance of matching what your visitors will search for, brilliant!";s:9:"more_info";s:456:"It's considered good practice to try to include your focus keyword(s) in the SEO description of your pages, because this is what people looking for the article are likely searching for. One could assume that because the slug does get indexed, the algorithm may favour slugs more closely aligned with the topic being searched.";s:10:"status_msg";s:46:"You've used your focus keyword in the page URL";}s:13:"keywords_used";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:148:"Focus keywords are intended to be unique so you're less likely to write duplicate content. Consider changing the focus keywords to something unique.";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. You can read more about this here. ";s:10:"status_msg";s:42:"You haven't used this focus keyword before";}s:16:"imgalts_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:307:"13/13 images on this page have alt text with your keyword(s) which is too much. Whilst itâs great that you have image alternative text with your focus keyword(s), you can also get penalized for having too many keywords on a page. Try to include your keyword(s) in image alt texts only when it makes sense.";s:9:"more_info";s:244:"Image alternative text attributes help search engines correctly index images, aid visually impaired readers, and the text is used in place of the image if it's unable to load. You should add alternative text for all images in your content.";s:10:"status_msg";s:61:"Too many of your image alt texts contain the focus keyword(s)";}s:14:"content_length";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:74:"Your content is longer than the recommend minimum of 300 words, excellent!";s:9:"more_info";s:798:"Content is ultimately the bread and butter of your SEO. Without words, your pages and posts will have a hard time ranking for the keywords you want them to. As a base for any article best practice suggests a minimum of 300 words, with 1000 being a good benchmark and 1600 being the optimal. Numerous studies have uncovered that longer content tends to perform better than shorter content, with pages having 1000 words or more performing best. Whilst optimizing your content for search engines is what we're going for here, a proven bi-product is that high quality long form articles also tend to get shared more on social platforms. With the increasing power of social media as a tool for traffic it's a nice flow on effect of writing those juicy high quality articles your readers are waiting for.";s:10:"status_msg";s:84:"The text contains 1020 words which is more than the recommended minimum of 300 words";}s:15:"keyword_density";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:196:"Currently you haven't used any keywords in your content. The recommended density is 1-3%. A low keyword density means your content has less chance of ranking highly for your chosen focus keywords.";s:9:"more_info";s:728:"Keyword density is all about making sure your content is populated with enough keywords to give it a better chance of appearing higher in search results. One way of making sure people will be able to find our content is using particular focus keywords, and using them as much as naturally possible in our content. In doing this we are trying to match up the keywords that people are likely to use when searching for this article or page, so try to get into your visitors mind and picture them typing a search into Google. While we recommend aiming for 1-3% density, remember content is king and you don't want your article to end up sounding like a robot. Get creative and utilize the page title, image caption, and subheadings.";s:10:"status_msg";s:33:"You haven't used any keywords yet";}s:11:"links_count";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:162:"Internal links help search engines crawl your website, effectively pointing them to more pages to index on your website. You've already added 31 links, nice work!";s:9:"more_info";s:1261:" Internal links are important for linking together related content. Search engines will 'crawl' through your website, indexing pages and posts as they go. To help them discover all the juicy content your website has to offer, it's wise to make sure your content has internal links built in for bots to follow and index.

External links don't benefit your SEO by having them in your own content, but you'll want to try and get as many other websites linking to your articles and pages as possible. Search engines treat links to your website as a 'third party vote' in favour of your website - like a vote of confidence. Since they're the hardest form of 'validation' to get (another website has to endorse you!) search engines weight them heavily when considering page rank. For more info: https://moz.com/learn/seo/internal-link

Note: This check is only looking at the content your page is outputting and doesn't include your main navigation. Blogs with lots of posts will benefit the most from this method, as it aids Google in finding and indexing all of your content, not just the latest articles. ";s:10:"status_msg";s:57:"You have 24 internal and 7 external links in your content";}s:13:"para_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:171:"You've included your focus keywords in the first paragraph of your content, which will help search engines and visitors quickly scope the topic of your article. Well done!";s:9:"more_info";s:541:"You should clearly formulate what your post is about in the first paragraph. In printed texts, a writer usually starts off with some kind of teaser, but there is no time for that if you are writing for the web. You only have seconds to gain your readerâs attention. Make sure the first paragraph tells the main message of your post. That way, you make it easy for your reader to figure out what your post is about. Doing this also tells Google what your post is about. Donât forget to put your focus keyword in that first paragraph! ";s:10:"status_msg";s:64:"The focus keyword appears in the first paragraph of your article";}s:20:"subheadings_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:153:"You've used keywords in 27 of your subheadings which will help both the user and search engines quickly figure out what your article is about, good work!";s:9:"more_info";s:478:"When trying to rank for certain keywords, those keywords should be found in as many key places as possible. Given that you're writing about the topic it only makes sense that you mention it in at least one of your subheadings. Headings are important for users as they break up your content and help readers figure out what the text is about. Same goes for search engines. With that said, don't force keywords into all your titles - keep it natural, readable, and use moderation!";s:10:"status_msg";s:46:"Your focus keyword was found in 27 subheadings";}}}

âI was extremely pleased with my experience at Southern Skies. Dr. Mario and his NP, Adrienne, removed a large basal cell on the top of my lip. It was a very extensive procedure resulting in more than 40 external stitches. Within a month the scar was barely noticeable. Much care and thought were given to how and where to make the incisions. Taking into account my facial creases, wrinkles, etc., the scar is almost completely hidden. I recommend them highly!â

With more than 40 years in business, Southern Skies Dermatology and Surgery is proud to serve the Alabama communities of Trussville in Birmingham, Pell City, and Gadsden. As the third generation of physicians in this practice, we focus primarily on skin cancer diagnosis and treatment, which has resulted in our practice becoming one of the highest-volume skin cancer exam, biopsy, and treatment groups in the United States.

Our mentality is that by focusing our energy and attention on one thing, skin cancer, we can do that one thing phenomenally well.Â  If youâre looking for expert dermatologists in Birmingham, Pell City, or Gadsden, schedule your appointment with us today and see why so many of our patients trust us with their skin health!

What Makes Us Different

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Divider.svg" title_text="Divider" _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" custom_margin="||||false|false" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="default" text_font="Roboto||||||||" text_line_height="33px" text_orientation_tablet="left" text_orientation_phone="center" text_orientation_last_edited="on|phone" global_colors_info="{}"]

At Southern Skies Dermatology, we feel that the best way to create a first-class experience for our patients is to first create a first-class experience for our employees. By prioritizing our work culture and making Southern Skies Dermatology and Surgery a positive, fun, rewarding place to work - we believe that we attract exceptional employees.Â 

Our practice administrator, Michelle Flowers, once told Dr. Mario, that we have to make sure we donât âoverwork and underpayâ our staff or they wonât take pride in working here, and they wonât stick around for the long haul. Dr. Mario took that to heart and wanted to go even further.

We reward our team with free take-out for lunch every Thursday (group vote decision), a spin-the-wheel birthday prize, quarterly cash rewards for being a reliably consistent employee, regular raises, unexpected bonuses for exceptional performance, and a healthy Christmas bonus, as well as a fabulously fun Christmas party.Â Â 

Phenomenal patient care comes from a team that is invested and ready to contribute to our practice. Weâve built a work family that includes doctors, advanced practice providers, front office staff, medical assistants, billing staff, laboratory personnel, many wonderful local vendors, and most importantly our patients whom we are extremely proud of.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section]

Consider changing the focus keywords to something unique.";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. You can read more about this here. As a base for any article best practice suggests a minimum of 300 words, with 1000 being a good benchmark and 1600 being the optimal. Numerous studies have uncovered that longer content tends to perform better than shorter content, with pages having 1000 words or more performing best. Whilst optimizing your content for search engines is what we're going for here, a proven bi-product is that high quality long form articles also tend to get shared more on social platforms. In doing this we are trying to match up the keywords that people are likely to use when searching for this article or page, so try to get into your visitors mind and picture them typing a search into Google. You've already added 31 links, nice work!";s:9:"more_info";s:1261:" Internal links are important for linking together related content. Search engines will 'crawl' through your website, indexing pages and posts as they go. To help them discover all the juicy content your website has to offer, it's wise to make sure your content has internal links built in for bots to follow and index.

External links don't benefit your SEO by having them in your own content, but you'll want to try and get as many other websites linking to your articles and pages as possible. Search engines treat links to your website as a 'third party vote' in favour of your website - like a vote of confidence. Since they're the hardest form of 'validation' to get (another website has to endorse you!) search engines weight them heavily when considering page rank. For more info: https://moz.com/learn/seo/internal-link

Note: This check is only looking at the content your page is outputting and doesn't include your main navigation. Blogs with lots of posts will benefit the most from this method, as it aids Google in finding and indexing all of your content, not just the latest articles. âI was extremely pleased with my experience at Southern Skies. Dr. Mario and his NP, Adrienne, removed a large basal cell on the top of my lip. It was a very extensive procedure resulting in more than 40 external stitches. Within a month the scar was barely noticeable. Much care and thought were given to how and where to make the incisions. Taking into account my facial creases, wrinkles, etc., the scar is almost completely hidden. I recommend them highly!â

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Rebecca Long, Gadsden" button_url_new_window="1" use_rating="on" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" global_colors_info="{}"]

With more than 40 years in business, Southern Skies Dermatology and Surgery is proud to serve the Alabama communities of Trussville in Birmingham, Pell City, and Gadsden. As the third generation of physicians in this practice, we focus primarily on skin cancer diagnosis and treatment, which has resulted in our practice becoming one of the highest-volume skin cancer exam, biopsy, and treatment groups in the United States.

Our mentality is that by focusing our energy and attention on one thing, skin cancer, we can do that one thing phenomenally well.Â  If youâre looking for expert dermatologists in Birmingham, Pell City, or Gadsden, schedule your appointment with us today and see why so many of our patients trust us with their skin health!

What Makes Us Different

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Divider-small-new-yellow.png" alt="Divider" title_text="Divider" _builder_version="4.19.0" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" width="180px" custom_margin="||||false|false" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="default" text_font="Roboto||||||||" text_line_height="33px" text_orientation_tablet="left" text_orientation_phone="center" text_orientation_last_edited="on|phone" global_colors_info="{}"]

At Southern Skies Dermatology, we feel that the best way to create a first-class experience for our patients is to first create a first-class experience for our employees. By prioritizing our work culture and making Southern Skies Dermatology and Surgery a positive, fun, rewarding place to work - we believe that we attract exceptional employees.Â 

Our practice administrator, Michelle Flowers, once told Dr. Mario, that we have to make sure we donât âoverwork and underpayâ our staff or they wonât take pride in working here, and they wonât stick around for the long haul. Dr. Mario took that to heart and wanted to go even further.

We reward our team with free take-out for lunch every Thursday (group vote decision), a spin-the-wheel birthday prize, quarterly cash rewards for being a reliably consistent employee, regular raises, unexpected bonuses for exceptional performance, and a healthy Christmas bonus, as well as a fabulously fun Christmas party.Â Â 

Phenomenal patient care comes from a team that is invested and ready to contribute to our practice. Weâve built a work family that includes doctors, advanced practice providers, front office staff, medical assistants, billing staff, laboratory personnel, many wonderful local vendors, and most importantly our patients whom we are extremely proud of.

Consider changing the focus keywords to something unique.";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. You can read more about this here. ";s:10:"status_msg";s:49:"You've used the focus keywords in another article";}s:16:"imgalts_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:309:"None of the images on this page have alt text containing your focus keyword. Add your keyword to one or more of your images, but be careful not to overdo it.";s:9:"more_info";s:244:"Image alternative text attributes help search engines correctly index images, aid visually impaired readers, and the text is used in place of the image if it's unable to load. You should add alternative text for all images in your content.";s:10:"status_msg";s:57:"None of your image alt texts contain the focus keyword(s)";}s:14:"content_length";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:74:"Your content is longer than the recommend minimum of 300 words, excellent!";s:9:"more_info";s:798:"Content is ultimately the bread and butter of your SEO. Without words, your pages and posts will have a hard time ranking for the keywords you want them to. As a base for any article best practice suggests a minimum of 300 words, with 1000 being a good benchmark and 1600 being the optimal. Numerous studies have uncovered that longer content tends to perform better than shorter content, with pages having 1000 words or more performing best. Whilst optimizing your content for search engines is what we're going for here, a proven bi-product is that high quality long form articles also tend to get shared more on social platforms. With the increasing power of social media as a tool for traffic it's a nice flow on effect of writing those juicy high quality articles your readers are waiting for.";s:10:"status_msg";s:84:"The text contains 1064 words which is more than the recommended minimum of 300 words";}s:15:"keyword_density";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:183:"Currently your keyword density is 0.72% which is below the recommended 1-3%. A low keyword density means your content has less chance of ranking highly for your chosen focus keywords.";s:9:"more_info";s:728:"Keyword density is all about making sure your content is populated with enough keywords to give it a better chance of appearing higher in search results. One way of making sure people will be able to find our content is using particular focus keywords, and using them as much as naturally possible in our content. In doing this we are trying to match up the keywords that people are likely to use when searching for this article or page, so try to get into your visitors mind and picture them typing a search into Google. While we recommend aiming for 1-3% density, remember content is king and you don't want your article to end up sounding like a robot. Get creative and utilize the page title, image caption, and subheadings.";s:10:"status_msg";s:36:"Your keyword density is less than 1%";}s:11:"links_count";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:162:"Internal links help search engines crawl your website, effectively pointing them to more pages to index on your website. You've already added 55 links, nice work!";s:9:"more_info";s:1261:" Internal links are important for linking together related content. Search engines will 'crawl' through your website, indexing pages and posts as they go. To help them discover all the juicy content your website has to offer, it's wise to make sure your content has internal links built in for bots to follow and index.

External links don't benefit your SEO by having them in your own content, but you'll want to try and get as many other websites linking to your articles and pages as possible. Search engines treat links to your website as a 'third party vote' in favour of your website - like a vote of confidence. Since they're the hardest form of 'validation' to get (another website has to endorse you!) search engines weight them heavily when considering page rank. For more info: https://moz.com/learn/seo/internal-link

Note: This check is only looking at the content your page is outputting and doesn't include your main navigation. Blogs with lots of posts will benefit the most from this method, as it aids Google in finding and indexing all of your content, not just the latest articles. ";s:10:"status_msg";s:58:"You have 38 internal and 17 external links in your content";}s:13:"para_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:169:"It's good practice to include your focus keywords in the first paragraph of your content so that search engines and visitors can quickly scope the topic of your article.";s:9:"more_info";s:541:"You should clearly formulate what your post is about in the first paragraph. In printed texts, a writer usually starts off with some kind of teaser, but there is no time for that if you are writing for the web. You only have seconds to gain your readerâs attention. Make sure the first paragraph tells the main message of your post. That way, you make it easy for your reader to figure out what your post is about. Doing this also tells Google what your post is about. Donât forget to put your focus keyword in that first paragraph! ";s:10:"status_msg";s:78:"You haven't included the focus keywords in the first paragraph of your article";}s:20:"subheadings_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:152:"You've used keywords in 6 of your subheadings which will help both the user and search engines quickly figure out what your article is about, good work!";s:9:"more_info";s:478:"When trying to rank for certain keywords, those keywords should be found in as many key places as possible. With that said, don't force keywords into all your titles - keep it natural, readable, and use moderation!";s:10:"status_msg";s:45:"Your focus keyword was found in 6 subheadings";}}}

One could assume that because the slug does get indexed, the algorithm may favour slugs more closely aligned with the topic being searched.";s:10:"status_msg";s:46:"You've used your focus keyword in the page URL";}s:13:"keywords_used";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:148:"Focus keywords are intended to be unique so you're less likely to write duplicate content. Consider changing the focus keywords to something unique.";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. You can read more about this here. Without words, your pages and posts will have a hard time ranking for the keywords you want them to. As a base for any article best practice suggests a minimum of 300 words, with 1000 being a good benchmark and 1600 being the optimal. Numerous studies have uncovered that longer content tends to perform better than shorter content, with pages having 1000 words or more performing best. Whilst optimizing your content for search engines is what we're going for here, a proven bi-product is that high quality long form articles also tend to get shared more on social platforms. With the increasing power of social media as a tool for traffic it's a nice flow on effect of writing those juicy high quality articles your readers are waiting for.";s:10:"status_msg";s:82:"The text contains 47 words which is less than the recommended minimum of 300 words";}s:15:"keyword_density";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:196:"Currently you haven't used any keywords in your content. The recommended density is 1-3%. A low keyword density means your content has less chance of ranking highly for your chosen focus keywords.";s:9:"more_info";s:728:"Keyword density is all about making sure your content is populated with enough keywords to give it a better chance of appearing higher in search results. One way of making sure people will be able to find our content is using particular focus keywords, and using them as much as naturally possible in our content. In doing this we are trying to match up the keywords that people are likely to use when searching for this article or page, so try to get into your visitors mind and picture them typing a search into Google. While we recommend aiming for 1-3% density, remember content is king and you don't want your article to end up sounding like a robot. You've already added 1 links, nice work!";s:9:"more_info";s:1261:" Internal links are important for linking together related content. Search engines will 'crawl' through your website, indexing pages and posts as they go. To help them discover all the juicy content your website has to offer, it's wise to make sure your content has internal links built in for bots to follow and index.

External links don't benefit your SEO by having them in your own content, but you'll want to try and get as many other websites linking to your articles and pages as possible. Search engines treat links to your website as a 'third party vote' in favour of your website - like a vote of confidence. Since they're the hardest form of 'validation' to get (another website has to endorse you!) search engines weight them heavily when considering page rank. For more info: https://moz.com/learn/seo/internal-link

Note: This check is only looking at the content your page is outputting and doesn't include your main navigation. Well done!";s:9:"more_info";s:541:"You should clearly formulate what your post is about in the first paragraph. In printed texts, a writer usually starts off with some kind of teaser, but there is no time for that if you are writing for the web. You only have seconds to gain your readerâs attention. Make sure the first paragraph tells the main message of your post. That way, you make it easy for your reader to figure out what your post is about. Doing this also tells Google what your post is about. Donât forget to put your focus keyword in that first paragraph! ";s:10:"status_msg";s:64:"The focus keyword appears in the first paragraph of your article";}s:20:"subheadings_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:152:"You've used keywords in 2 of your subheadings which will help both the user and search engines quickly figure out what your article is about, good work!";s:9:"more_info";s:478:"When trying to rank for certain keywords, those keywords should be found in as many key places as possible. Headings are important for users as they break up your content and help readers figure out what the text is about. Same goes for search engines. With that said, don't force keywords into all your titles - keep it natural, readable, and use moderation!";s:10:"status_msg";s:45:"Your focus keyword was found in 2 subheadings";}}}

We recommend you have at least one subheading.";s:9:"more_info";s:478:"When trying to rank for certain keywords, those keywords should be found in as many key places as possible. âI was extremely pleased with my experience at Southern Skies. Dr. Mario and his NP, Adrienne, removed a large basal cell on the top of my lip. It was a very extensive procedure resulting in more than 40 external stitches. Within a month the scar was barely noticeable. Much care and thought were given to how and where to make the incisions. Taking into account my facial creases, wrinkles, etc., the scar is almost completely hidden. I recommend them highly!â

âIâm very pleased with the care and concern of this staff. Dr. M did a great job on my ear. The reconstruction looks wonderful. You have to look really close to tell anything was done. They are professionals, but they treat me like family.âÂ 

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Michael Brown, Ohatchee" button_url_new_window="1" use_rating="on" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" global_colors_info="{}" theme_builder_area="post_content"]

âToday was my doctor visit day at Southern Skies. I never want to go to the doctor, but I know how important it s for my health. I can say that Dr. Mario and his staff are very professional in their treatment. They make me feel secure with their treatment and knowledge.â

About Dr. Malia Downing

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Divider-small-new-yellow.png" title_text="Divider" align="center" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" locked="off" global_colors_info="%91%93" theme_builder_area="post_content"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.27.4" _module_preset="399dc1c6-5b92-4bd9-a1dd-0455d30e3551" text_font_size="17px" link_text_color="#0B61C7" global_colors_info="%91%93" link_text_color__hover_enabled="on|hover" link_text_color__hover="#007DBD" theme_builder_area="post_content"]

Dr. Downing was raised in Hawaii and received her undergraduate degree from the College of Saint Scholastica in Duluth, MN where she played collegiate soccer and graduated Summa Cum Laude. She was awarded her medical doctorate from the University of North Dakota, graduating second in her class. Upon completing medical school, she moved to Kansas City, KS where she did her medical internship and dermatology residency at the University of Kansas. Dr. Downing completed her fellowship training in Micrographic Surgery and Dermatologic Oncology and Cosmetic Dermatologic Surgery at Surgical Dermatology Group in Birmingham, AL where she received advanced training in the management of skin cancers and reconstructive techniques.

She was also a regular volunteer at the KC Health Center, providing dermatologic care to uninsured patients. She is a member of the American Academy of Dermatology, the American Society for Dermatologic Surgery, the American College of Mohs Surgery, and the Alpha Omega Alpha Medical Honor Society. In her free time, Dr. Downing enjoys scuba diving, spear fishing, hiking, skiing, working on her family's farm in Hawaii, and spending time with her husband, sons, and dogs.

Our goal is to be easily accessible to our patients and educate them on any topics related to skin cancer, skin disease, or skin health, which is why we encourage you to contact us with any questions you have by filling out this form. Our front desk team monitors your responses daily and is happy to respond appropriately!

With a variety of experts on our medical staff, we often consult each other to give you the best answers and results. Weâre happy to provide you with personalized answers, and consultations, and schedule an appointment with you when it is necessary.

Consider changing the focus keywords to something unique.";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. You can read more about this here. ";s:10:"status_msg";s:42:"You haven't used this focus keyword before";}s:16:"imgalts_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:378:"Images are a great addition to any piece of content and itâs highly recommended to have imagery on your pages. Something, anything, is better than nothing.";s:9:"more_info";s:798:"Content is ultimately the bread and butter of your SEO. Without words, your pages and posts will have a hard time ranking for the keywords you want them to. As a base for any article best practice suggests a minimum of 300 words, with 1000 being a good benchmark and 1600 being the optimal. Numerous studies have uncovered that longer content tends to perform better than shorter content, with pages having 1000 words or more performing best. Whilst optimizing your content for search engines is what we're going for here, a proven bi-product is that high quality long form articles also tend to get shared more on social platforms. With the increasing power of social media as a tool for traffic it's a nice flow on effect of writing those juicy high quality articles your readers are waiting for.";s:10:"status_msg";s:81:"The text contains 0 words which is less than the recommended minimum of 300 words";}s:15:"keyword_density";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:196:"Currently you haven't used any keywords in your content. A low keyword density means your content has less chance of ranking highly for your chosen focus keywords.";s:9:"more_info";s:728:"Keyword density is all about making sure your content is populated with enough keywords to give it a better chance of appearing higher in search results. One way of making sure people will be able to find our content is using particular focus keywords, and using them as much as naturally possible in our content. In doing this we are trying to match up the keywords that people are likely to use when searching for this article or page, so try to get into your visitors mind and picture them typing a search into Google. While we recommend aiming for 1-3% density, remember content is king and you don't want your article to end up sounding like a robot. Get creative and utilize the page title, image caption, and subheadings.";s:10:"status_msg";s:33:"You haven't used any keywords yet";}s:11:"links_count";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:202:"Internal links help search engines crawl your website, effectively pointing them to more pages to index on your website. You should consider adding at least one internal link to another related article.";s:9:"more_info";s:1261:" Internal links are important for linking together related content. Search engines will 'crawl' through your website, indexing pages and posts as they go. To help them discover all the juicy content your website has to offer, it's wise to make sure your content has internal links built in for bots to follow and index.

External links don't benefit your SEO by having them in your own content, but you'll want to try and get as many other websites linking to your articles and pages as possible. Search engines treat links to your website as a 'third party vote' in favour of your website - like a vote of confidence. Since they're the hardest form of 'validation' to get (another website has to endorse you!) search engines weight them heavily when considering page rank. For more info: https://moz.com/learn/seo/internal-link

Note: This check is only looking at the content your page is outputting and doesn't include your main navigation. Blogs with lots of posts will benefit the most from this method, as it aids Google in finding and indexing all of your content, not just the latest articles. âI was extremely pleased with my experience at Southern Skies. Dr. Mario and his NP, Adrienne, removed a large basal cell on the top of my lip. It was a very extensive procedure resulting in more than 40 external stitches. Within a month the scar was barely noticeable. Much care and thought were given to how and where to make the incisions. Taking into account my facial creases, wrinkles, etc., the scar is almost completely hidden. I recommend them highly!â

About Emma Stephens, PA

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Divider-small-new-yellow.png" title_text="Divider" align="center" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" locked="off" global_colors_info="%91%93" theme_builder_area="post_content"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.27.4" _module_preset="399dc1c6-5b92-4bd9-a1dd-0455d30e3551" text_font_size="17px" link_text_color="#0B61C7" global_colors_info="%91%93" link_text_color__hover_enabled="on|hover" link_text_color__hover="#007DBD" theme_builder_area="post_content"]

Emma was born and raised in Madison, AL, and graduated from Bob Jones High School. She went to Samford University, where she earned her BSN in Nursing in 2015. She worked in the cardiac ICU for three years before she entered the Physician Assistant Studies program at UAB, where she earned her Masters Degree. Later that year, she married her husband, Richard Stephens. He is also a PA who performs cardiac surgery at UAB. Emma discovered her passion for dermatology during clinical rotations in PA school. Initially after graduating, Emma worked in the ICUâs at St. Vincentâs Birmingham during COVID until she had the opportunity to transition to dermatology in 2021. Emma and Richard now live in Hoover, AL with their maltipoo named Obi. Emma has three step-children: Noah, Ella, and Mason. Richard and Emma are huge foodies and love to travel. In her spare time, Emma loves to thrift, renovate her house, and spend time with her husband and dog on the sofa binging their latest favorite show. Emma looks forward to caring for you at Southern Skies Dermatology!

Consider changing the focus keywords to something unique.";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. You can read more about this here. In doing this we are trying to match up the keywords that people are likely to use when searching for this article or page, so try to get into your visitors mind and picture them typing a search into Google.
